report_title: Beauty, Cosmetics & Fragrance Stores in the US
executive_summary: The beauty, cosmetics and fragrance stores industry has faced challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic and elevated inflation, but has largely benefited from the ongoing economic recovery. Revenue grew at an estimated CAGR of 2.6% to $55.4 billion over the past five years, including a 1.5% jump in 2024. Demand for skin and hair care products soared during the pandemic, while demand for cosmetics declined. Inflation in 2022 negatively impacted demand due to weaker disposable income. However, the recovery has boosted revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Macroeconomic conditions contribute to changes in demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many cosmetics and beauty products are generally considered to be discretionary in nature. As a result, demand for beauty products can weaken when economic conditions are unfavorable. The growing popularity of skincare and hair products prevented retailers from facing drastic revenue losses during the initial stages of the pandemic. Although revenue continued to grow during this time, elevated consumer uncertainty resulted in minimal revenue gains. Elevated inflation in 2022 directly impacted demand for beauty products. Millennials and GenX account for the large majority of retailers' customer pool. Manufacturers now produce cosmetics that appeal to this group by reformulating skincare products to yield better results and adding skincare properties to other cosmetics. Another market that manufacturers decided to target is male cosmetics. Cosmetics formulated for men have packaging and scents that appeal to a male audience. Men's inexperience with beauty stores results in most of these sales taking place online. Younger consumers are becoming increasingly aware of consumerism's impact on the environment, increasing demand for naturally derived and eco-friendly personal products. This has pushed retailers to shift their product offerings. Foreign cosmetic brands are becoming increasingly popular among domestic consumers. As consumers have become increasingly curious about foreign brands, particularly Asian beauty products, retailers have kept them in stock to adapt to changing consumer preferences.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers are becoming more comfortable purchasing cosmetics and personal care products online, lowering traffic at traditional stores, which particularly harms smaller retailers. Online-exclusive retailers are also strong competitors that offer special promotions and discounts, such as free shipping and free samples, to attract customers. Specialized stores face significant competition from other industries, including department stores, drugstores and mass merchandisers. future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Retailers Offer New Products to Attract Customers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Retailers will offer more antiaging, environmentally friendly, cruelty-free and natural products to match changing preferences. Younger buyers starting with skincare/makeup early will drive gains.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Collaborating With Beauty Influencers Can Drive Traffic
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Celebrity endorsements and influencer collabs on Instagram/TikTok will attract attention and boost demand for trendy products, especially focusing on brand values.

products_and_services.product_description: Haircare products include hair sprays, masks and styling products. The haircare market has gained more traction as consumers value haircare routines and products more.

Consumers are becoming increasingly aware of the benefits of having a skincare routine, boosting demand for skincare products. Large investments in research and development at the manufacturing level resulted in new skincare products with added benefits, sparking interest from consumers in skincare.

Cosmetics are commonly considered discretionary products, causing their sale to be directly affected by changes in disposable income. Consumer preferences for beauty products are everchanging as most beauty and fashion trends are cyclical.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Changes in consumer spending impact cosmetic sales as beauty products are commonly considered discretionary. When consumer spending rises, customers tend to spend more on discretionary products like makeup and perfumes. On the other hand, when consumer spending weakens, buyers become more likely to cut back on discretionary purchases, harming sales.

During the pandemic, consumers had significantly fewer events to wear makeup to as social distancing regulations prevented gatherings and events from being held. This trend pushed many consumers to focus on adopting a skincare routine, enabling the segment to grow.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Fair Packaging and Labeling Act requires all products to be properly labeled with accurate and complete information on their contents. The act also requires manufacturers to disclose the net quantity of the product, information about the manufacturer and any warning labels. The act aims to help consumers make informed decisions before purchasing products.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938
regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA oversees the safety of beauty, cosmetics, and fragrance products. Manufacturers must prove their products are safe before marketing. This regulation also covers product labeling and distribution, aiming to protect consumers.

California's Cosmetics Organic Labeling laws mandate that any cosmetic product claiming to use organic ingredients must be clear in its wording. While components can be labeled as organic, final products cannot. Other regulations are expected to follow suit, particularly as the current definitions of natural and organic products are imprecise and open to interpretation and abuse.

The FDA regulates beauty, cosmetics, and fragrance stores to ensure product safety and proper labeling. These businesses must comply with the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, which mandates accurate ingredient lists and warnings for allergic reactions. For instance, Johnson & Johnson faced lawsuits for undisclosed risks in their talc-based products. Non-compliance can lead to product recalls, damaging brand reputation and customer trust.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Large Brands Tend to Be More Profitable
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Like for many other retail industries, reaching economies of scale plays a major role in a company's profit margin. Larger companies, like Ulta and Sephora, can reach favorable deals with major suppliers and benefit from significant brand recognition, resulting in significantly higher profit. Smaller stores serving local markets often have lower foot traffic in stores and fail to build a significant online presence, resulting in significantly lower profit and pulling the average profit margin down.
Unfavorable economic conditions, including elevated consumer uncertainty and rising inflation, pushed consumers to lower discretionary spending, causing the average profit margin to shrink.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Are High Among Retailers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include makeup, fragrances, hair products and other beauty items. Like in most retail industries, purchase costs are the most significant expense, as retailers purchase beauty products from manufacturers and wholesalers to resell directly to customers at a marked-up rate. Retailers often opt to offer free samples to consumers to grow exposure, encourage larger purchases and promote new products. These samples increase purchasing costs for retailers.

Beauty products manufacturers are directly impacted by changes in input prices, including alcohols, chemicals, dyes, essential oils and minerals. These inputs have endured significant volatility in recent years, pushing purchase costs upward.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Growth in E-Commerce Harms Traditional Retailers
volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers are becoming increasingly comfortable purchasing cosmetics online and from non-specialty stores, increasing traffic for sellers like Amazon, Walmart or Target and slowing down sales from traditional retailers. Many specialized stores, including Sephora and Ulta, have developed their online presence by launching their own websites, enabling consumers to purchase beauty products online. Adopting these capabilities enables specialized stores to compete with larger online retailers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Retailers aim to adopt new technologies to retain existing customers and attract new ones. Technologies like Skincare iQ, Color iQ and Fragrance iQ offer customized product selections, matching cosmetic colors and scents to clients' preferences. These services give consumers a personalized shopping experience, encouraging more consumers to visit stores. Adopting these systems has also made it easier for consumers to shop online for products that match their needs, driving traffic for large brands.

Retailers have been increasingly adopting technologies that help with day-to-day operations. include point-of-sale, inventory management and other systems that support operations. Computer-scanning cash registers, as well as automated warehouse equipment, are becoming more popular and accessible for smaller operators.
Most innovation that impacts the industry happens at the manufacturing level.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market, or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: While industry operators typically retail a diverse range of beauty products, players must specialize in industry-relevant products.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: While some products, such as perfume, are heavily influenced by the economy's health, others, such as skin care, are generally bought regardless of economic strength. During economic uncertainty, consumers might opt to purchase more affordable products, slowing revenue growth.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Retailers look to distinguish themselves in this industry and with external players by providing superior customer service. This relies on companies investing in high-skilled employees.

FAQs.question: Do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: While some retailers are vertically integrated and manufacture their own products, most other large operators contract directly with manufacturers. Small retailers, however, may make their purchases through a wholesaler.

FAQs.question: How does your company utilize new technology, like RFID tags, in its operations?
FAQs.answer: New technologies, such as RFID, have become increasingly popular among retailers, enabling them to track shipments and inventory.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automation cannot significantly reduce wages in this industry as retailers rely heavily on solid customer service to maintain sales.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Changes in regulation surrounding organic beauty products could significantly impact the popularity of products stocked by beauty stores. However, this regulation has yet to be determined.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: Large retailers often have in-house compliance teams, while smaller players rely on personal research and industry associations to comply with new regulations.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Although the average industry profit margin has contracted in recent years, industry profitability is generally higher than the retail sector average.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for cashflow seasonality?
FAQs.answer: While demand may boom for some industry retailers during the holidays, consumers demand industry goods throughout the year.

FAQs.question: How can you improve the image and layout of your store?
FAQs.answer: The store layout and display of stock must encourage customers to make purchases and reinforce the company image. Merchandising and product placement are of key importance.

FAQs.question: Do you change displays based on season or events?
FAQs.answer: The store layout and display of stock must encourage customers to make purchases and reinforce the company image. Merchandising and product placement are of key importance.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a reputation for high-quality customer service? How do you hire and retain the best possible employees?
FAQs.answer: In line with its customer-centric focus and reliance on one-on-one selling techniques, floor staff need to provide high-quality customer service, particularly within the prestige segment of the industry.

FAQs.question: What stock control measures does your company use?
FAQs.answer: As with most retail segments, industry players should ensure that adequate stock controls are in place to reduce inventory costs and increase stock turns.

FAQs.question: Which products frequently sell out, and which products experience the lowest demand?
FAQs.answer: As with most retail segments, industry players should ensure that adequate stock controls are in place to reduce inventory costs and increase stock turns.

FAQs.question: How do you compete with online retailers? How do you differentiate your business from online stores that sell similar items?
FAQs.answer: E-commerce stores pose a significant threat to the brick-and-mortar stores that comprise this industry because online retailers can offer lower prices due to low overhead costs, wider inventories and the ease of direct shipping.

FAQs.question: Do you track changes in population and key demographics? How can you better cater to the key market of women between 35 and 54?
FAQs.answer: Women are the largest market for this industry, with 35- to 54-year-olds representing the most significant industry customer base, and millennial women growing as a share of revenue. An expansion in this group's size and income level will boost industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you find that sales increase when disposable incomes are high? Have you made any pricing changes to attract and retain customers?
FAQs.answer: Changes in per capita disposable income affect demand for cosmetics because these products are considered to be discretionary. When per capita disposable income levels rise, consumers can spend more on beauty products, cosmetics and fragrances.
